content.body: > How does it work? Turns out oniguruma, the regexp engine ruby uses, supports 'calling' previously defined capture groups with the \g<...> syntax
content.formatted_body: How does it work? Turns out oniguruma, the regexp engine ruby uses, supports 'calling' previously defined capture groups with the \g<...> syntax

content.body: I brought that to committee but it didn't get stage 1

Well, it was part of the big regexp features proposal that I had to break down into smaller proposals. I haven't presented it on its own yet because it seemed like it would have a lower likelihood of success, so it hasn't been a priority
content.formatted_body: Well, it was part of the big regexp features proposal that I had to break down into smaller proposals. I haven't presented it on its own yet because it seemed like it would have a lower likelihood of success, so it hasn't been a priority

content.body: regex should not have that feature
It's extremely valuable and let's you compose a lot of small reusable patterns. It's very good for parsing ISO-8601 dates to spec
but i think any complex enough to warrant it should not be a regex anymore
* but i think anything complex enough to warrant it should not be a regex anymore

m.new_content.body: but i think anything complex enough to warrant it should not be a regex anymore
